üåüMountains Climb on the Wunda Chair
üá∫üá∏
- One of the very challenging intermediate exercises on the Wunda Chair is Mountain Climb.
- Many don‚Äôt realize that this exercise turns around for an even more challenging version called Reverse Mountain Climb. 
- Both can be practiced on the High Chair for added support by holding the sides of the chair and more spring resistance. 

üáßüá∑
- Um dos exerc√≠cios intermedi√°rios mais desafiadores na Cadeira Wunda √© o Mountain Climb.
- Muitos n√£o percebem que este exerc√≠cio se transforma em uma vers√£o ainda mais desafiadora, chamada Reverse Mountain Climb. 
- Ambos podem ser praticados na High Chair para maior suporte, segurando nas laterais da cadeira e aumentando a resist√™ncia das molas.

üá™üá∏
- Uno de los ejercicios intermedios m√°s desafiantes en la Silla Wunda es la Mountain Climb.
- Muchos desconocen que este ejercicio se convierte en una versi√≥n a√∫n m√°s desafiante llamada Reverse Mountain Climb.

#pilates #pilatesinstructor #pilateslovers #pilatesstudio #inspiration #classicalpilates #authenticpilateslearningcenter #aplcbrasil #aplcusa #aplcespa√±a

P I L A T E S üíôR e f o r m e r 

Here are a few ‚Äúclassical Pilates‚Äù exercises designed by Joseph Pilates for the Reformer. 

During World War I, Pilates, who was living in England, was interned as a German "enemy alien". He used this time to develop his fitness program, which he later called "Contrology," focusing on mind-body connection and core strength. 

While in the internment camp, Pilates began teaching his fitness methods to fellow internees, and later, he worked as an orderly in a hospital on the Isle of Man, where he developed his apparatus by attaching bed springs to hospital beds to help rehabilitate patients unable to walk. 

The springs he used to help patients move and strengthen their muscles while bedridden became the inspiration for the iconic Pilates Reformer. 

After the war, Pilates returned to Germany and continued to study fitness and movement, eventually collaborating with experts in dance and physical exercise. He later emigrated to the United States, where he and his wife Clara opened a studio in New York City, where he worked with dancers and athletes. 

Today, Pilates is more popular than ever because it helps with everything. It‚Äôs one of the best workouts for your mind and body. Make sure you work with a certified Pilates teacher who has experience. 

üî∏First Video: 
Footwork-‚Äúrunning or prancing‚Äù. I like to do a set with the pelvis neutral & another set with the pelvis lifted a few inches off the mat. The footwork exercises were meant to activate all the important muscles in our feet similar to acupressure. The feet are responsible for three quarters of our body & help with balance. 

üî∏Second Video:
‚ÄúThe Shoulder Bridge‚Äù which is a great way to work your glutes and back while stretching the front of your hips and shoulders. Adding the magic circle and light dumbbells makes it even tougher. 

üî∏Third Video:
‚ÄúFeet in Straps‚Äù-Leg Circles are a favorite for most Pilates lovers because it massages our hips and feels amazing. 

üî∏4th Video
‚ÄúThe Shoulder Bridge‚Äù w heels together toes apart.

üí• Following safety protocol and instructor

  class

  corrections, do not muscle through

In this class there are 3 levels of difficulty for the same exercise. Side plank on the ground for those that may have shoulder issues and need a modification (or just not comfortable doing a side plank on the reformers just yet, but can do everytjing else during a level 2 class), side plank on the reformer with no movement, and side plank with movement for progression.

One of the hardest moves I‚Äôve ever done. It‚Äôs not a traditional Pilates exercise, but most of us consider this part of the work now‚Äîand for good reason. It‚Äôs a big strength move. To truly build strength, we must challenge and overload the body.

Notice how I‚Äôm moving my trunk through space. Instead  of flexing the spine, I‚Äôm treating this as a plank‚Äìside bend concept, adding the one arm push up takes this over the top.

‚ÄúAbove all, learn how to breathe correctly‚Äù - Joseph Pilates 

This quote emphasizes the foundational, life-sustaining power of breath, much like the natural forces depicted in Quinn‚Äôs sculpture series. 

@amyalpers used this archival exercise, which we nicknamed archival monkey, and a photo of Lorenzo Quinn‚Äôs The Force of Nature sculpture as ideas in her Advanced Reformer Class. 

Just as the sculptures convey nature's raw, dynamic energy, Joseph Pilates highlights the vital force of breath as the key to sustaining life and strength and bodying the power that flows through all movement and existence. 

There is nothing more poetic than witnessing Amy connecting, layering in the art and science of contrology within her classes through her understanding of Pilates and the world around her.

Join Amy at our Archival Weekend, October 3-5th, or just in classes in-person and online during the week. 

Sign up today to secure your spot through the Momence App.

don‚Äôt be a major looser and learn some history about how the core principles and ethos of pilates is inclusivity. joseph pilates created the pilates exercise to rehabilitate fallen soldiers during World War I and thus started using hospital beds and their springs to create exercises for injured, sick, and disabled soldiers. which later laid the foundation for the pilates equipment you see today. fun fact: joseph pilates was inspired by eastern ideas about health and physical fitness such as yoga, tai chi, and zen meditation. he also was inspired by the stretches of cats üêà (how cute!). therefor pilates is a principle and practice that anyone can do, including the big girls. that‚Äôs all for my ted talk.

‚ú®Ô∏èTake it back to basics with today's Fitness Pilates Knee drop, such a simple exercise thats great for the whole core üëç

We are over 50 but not quite 60. The three of us have a lifetime of movement between us.  It is challenging  for fitness professionals to cope with the changes in our bodies. The key is to adapt and keep moving.  @colettevandyk is ranked 5th nationally in her age group as a duathlete. (Duathons nor triathlons). She is in the 98% in her age group as an ultramarathoner. @larisalotz has over 20 years in the industry as a functional trainer. (And she trains me) We both have two young adult children. It shows when you make movement a priority in your life. You don‚Äôt have to run marathons but try to move your body every day.  Share this with a friend who needs a little inspiration to get up and move.

You can workout with me lots of different ways.

This is what happens when one travels with family to visit #PilatesTeachers that are part of your extended #PilatesFamily.... everybody gets lots of love. üíúüíúüíú

Michelle Leach and Alexa Idama have created two beautiful,  vibrant, welcoming Classical Pilates training studios in Atlanta. Both were active participants in many PSS workouts since its inception. 

What a joy it was to be able to connect ....IRL... touch, hug, honor, and appreciate each other and the work being accomplished, respectively, in the community.

Michelle and I have known and worked together since 2017. She moved to Atlanta  3 years ago, and this won't be the last time I visit her in this glorious space. 

I told Alexa there was no way I could travel to Atlanta and not pop in for a hug, kiss, and smile.... IRL, as we have only "experienced" each other via social media.

As you can see,  it was a TT weekend and so, meeting her in her new training center filled with a room full of apprentices, on the path to changing their lives and movement, was truly a special treat, for me as "big sis."

Having my brother and family with me to capture the moments with both of them was the icing on the cake. 

My heart is full. This was all I had hoped, planned and envisioned for the afternoon. üíõüíõüíõ

#PilatesFamily
#PilatesTeachers
#ClassicalPilatesTraining
#PilatesLifestyle 
#PilatesSisters

It requires trainees to not only understand the system of Pilates but make connections with exercises on various apparatus without reinventing the wheel and pivot when necessary! 
.

After nearly 450 hours of formal Pilates training (almost three years of classes, three days a week - two reformer and one mat), plus daily 5‚Äì15 minute home practice and a dozen 1:1 sessions after having Dean to heal my diastasis, I am officially a certified mat Pilates instructor! ‚ú®
-
I‚Äôve completely fallen in love with the intentionality and flow of Pilates. It‚Äôs transformed not only my training but also my body: my strength in weightlifting has increased, my posture has improved (feet, ankles, glute balance, even scoliosis), and my diastasis has fully closed. My core has never looked better - I always joke that I have no business having an 8-pack after two kids just 19 months apart, but I credit it all to Pilates.
-
Pilates has also been a game changer for my pelvic floor strength and mind‚Äìmuscle connection, which has carried over into everything - from better glute development, to improved core definition, to more confidence and yes, even incredible sex.
-
I‚Äôll be sharing many of my favorite flows here, and they‚Äôll also be part of my next challenge (starting October 13!). I can‚Äôt wait to bring these workouts to you in a more structured way. I know not everyone has access to in-person classes, so my hope is to help you experience the same love and benefits of Pilates that I have. üôèüèº
